name: q16_5
probTex: Let $\{f_n\}$ be a sequence of analytic functions on a region $\Omega$ which converges uniformly to a function $f$. Prove that $f$ is also analytic.\nLet $\{f_n^{(k)}\}$ be the sequence of $k^{th}$ derivatives of $f_n$. Show that, on every closed disc $\overline{B_r(a)}\subset\Omega, f_n^{(k)}$ converges uniformly to $f^{(k)}$.
solnTex:
Let $\gamma$ be any closed path in $\Omega$ which encircles only points also in $\Omega$. By Cauchy's integral theorem,
\[\int_\gamma f_n(z)dz=0.\]
Then uniform convergence means we can swap integral and limit, so
\[\int_\gamma f(z)dz=\lim\int_\gamma f_n(z)dz=0.\]
Thus $f$ is analytic by Morera's theorem. Moreover, by Cauchy's integral formula ($z_0\in\Omega$ and $\gamma$ is a small loop around $z_0$)
\[f^{(k)}(z)= rac{k!}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{f(z)}{(z-z_0)^{k+1}}dz=\lim rac{k!}{2\pi i}\int_\gamma rac{f_n(z)}{(z-z_0)^{k+1}}dz=f_n^{(k)}(z_0).\]
Uniform convergence for the middle equality above comes from the fact that $f_n$ converges uniformly to begin with, and the fact that $\overline{B_r(a)}$ is compact.
